lens.lens_summary: This lens reveals how a pragmatic, cost-conscious guest navigating an unfamiliar shared-living model needs clear goals, immediate feedback, and a sense of control at every phase — precisely the conditions Csikszentmihalyi identifies as prerequisites for enjoyment and continued engagement — and how the absence of these conditions produces hesitation, deferral, and dropout risk.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Shomit arrived through an ad, already knowing the location (Upper West Side) and rough schedule (six weeks, Monday through Friday). His discovery was externally triggered but immediately practical: he has a real housing need because he works in NYC part-time but cannot justify a full-time lease. The book extract illuminates that Shomit is not seeking pleasure (a comfortable hotel) but rather a structured solution that matches his life pattern. Csikszentmihalyi's distinction between pleasure and enjoyment maps directly: Shomit wants more than comfort — he wants a living arrangement that fits his specific work rhythm without overpaying. The discovery phase works when the external trigger (the ad) connects to a felt need and creates enough clarity to move forward. Shomit's immediate engagement on the call shows the ad successfully created a clear initial goal.

user_state.emotional_state: Pragmatically curious but not urgent. Shomit is exploring options, not desperate. He speaks in measured terms: 'six weeks is like, uh, cause that's what I know for now. Right. And then maybe more after that.' (line 4). There is openness without commitment.
user_state.knowledge_level: Shomit knows the basic proposition (a furnished apartment, weekly schedule) but does not understand the Split Lease model (co-tenancy, bid system, matching). He treats this as a standard short-term rental inquiry until the agent explains otherwise.
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing with intent. He responded to an ad and is on a call, which indicates real interest, but he has no platform account and has not seen any listings yet.
user_state.data_available: Location preference (Upper West Side but open to other areas), schedule (six weeks starting soon, four nights Monday-Thursday), rough budget anchor ($2,500/month full lease as reference point), contact information (email shared on call).

reasons: The Split Lease model is novel and unfamiliar — Shomit has never used anything like it, and the concept of 'ghost roommates' sharing his space requires a mental model shift that could produce confusion or distrust.

Shomit has an immediate need (arriving April 15) that Split Lease explicitly cannot serve ('this is not that opportunity' — line 27). This gap between immediate need and available timeline may cause him to solve his problem elsewhere and never return.

He has existing mental models from long experience renting in NYC ('I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time' — line 67) that may make the Split Lease model feel unnecessarily complex.
dropout_risk.evidence: Shomit says: 'All of this sounds good. Right? I mean, it doesn't solve my question for next week, but that's fine.' (line 38). The 'but that's fine' signals acceptance of the limitation, but also reveals that his most pressing need is unmet. Csikszentmihalyi: 'Activities that provide enjoyment are often those that have been designed for this very purpose' (line 329-330) — if the discovery experience feels like it was not designed to serve Shomit's actual situation, engagement drops.

key_quotes.quote: you responded to our ad for the apartment was, uh, uh, six weeks, Monday
key_quotes.relevance: Shows the discovery trigger was an ad with specific parameters (location, duration, schedule). The ad created a clear goal, which Csikszentmihalyi identifies as essential for engagement.

key_quotes.quote: I did live in New York for a long time. That's where I work, but I'm not there full-time so it's hard to justify getting an apartment also, as you imagine, it's expensive.
key_quotes.relevance: Reveals the core need driving discovery: a cost-effective solution for part-time NYC living. This is the felt gap that makes Split Lease potentially valuable.

key_quotes.quote: There are two main strategies we can adopt to improve the quality of life. The first is to try making external conditions match our goals. The second is to change how we experience external conditions to make them fit our goals better.
key_quotes.relevance: Shomit is pursuing the first strategy — changing external conditions (finding affordable part-time housing) to match his goal of working in NYC without overpaying. The platform must help him achieve this external-conditions strategy clearly.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Shomit has not yet entered the search phase at the time of this call — he will only begin searching after receiving his account link. But the call reveals critical pre-search requirements. He explicitly wants to see multiple options ('No, I want to see what the other options are' — line 52) and has clear filtering criteria: location (Upper West Side preferred but flexible), budget ($1,500/month or less), schedule (4 nights Monday-Thursday). The book extract's concept of challenge-skill balance is directly relevant: the search interface must present an appropriate level of complexity. Too many options without filters will overwhelm (anxiety); too few options or an opaque system will bore or frustrate. The agent's promise that the website will let him 'play with' options dynamically (line 49) sets up an expectation of interactive, feedback-rich search — exactly what Csikszentmihalyi prescribes for maintaining engagement.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautiously interested but firmly non-committal. Shomit repeatedly defers action: 'I'll still hold off. See the other ones.' (line 55). He wants to gather information before making any move.
user_state.knowledge_level: Shomit now understands (from the call) that multiple properties exist, that pricing is dynamic based on nights and weeks, and that the website will show options. But he has not yet experienced the platform's search interface.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating. He is willing to receive information and look at options, but explicitly refuses to enter even a non-binding bid until he has surveyed the full landscape.
user_state.data_available: Budget ceiling ($1,500/month), location flexibility (Upper West Side preferred, other areas acceptable), night count preference (4 nights), day preferences (Monday-Thursday), duration (six weeks minimum, possibly longer), timeline (spring/summer start preferred).

reasons: The transition from phone call to platform is a critical handoff. Shomit was told he will receive an email with an account link. If the email is delayed, unclear, or the platform does not match what was described on the call, he may never complete the transition.

Shomit explicitly declined to enter a bid even after being told it is non-binding — three times (lines 52, 55, 61). This suggests he needs to feel a strong sense of control before taking any action on the platform. If the search experience feels like it pushes him toward commitment too early, he will withdraw.

His budget of $1,500/month may limit viable options. The agent mentioned properties costing $2,500/month (line 71). If search results surface mostly unaffordable listings, the experience will feel like a mismatch — what Csikszentmihalyi calls the anxiety zone when challenges exceed skills/resources.
dropout_risk.evidence: Shomit says: 'No, I want to see what the other options are. And also, I'm not sure if when I would start.' (line 52). Two forms of uncertainty compound: what is available, and when he can begin. Csikszentmihalyi: 'Enjoyment appears at the boundary between boredom and anxiety, when the challenges are just balanced with the person's capacity to act.' (lines 398-400). If the search phase does not balance available options against Shomit's constraints, he will land in the anxiety zone and leave.

key_quotes.quote: Other options are good. I like the upper west side, but it's not the only place. I mean, there's other options that might be good to know about.
key_quotes.relevance: Shows Shomit wants breadth before depth. The search phase must surface multiple options that match his criteria to sustain engagement.

key_quotes.quote: you can play with that on the website and it will give you all options dynamically. So you can see that.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent sets up an expectation of dynamic, interactive search with immediate feedback — which is exactly what Csikszentmihalyi's flow model requires (clear goals and immediate feedback).

key_quotes.quote: the experience usually occurs when we confront tasks we have a chance of completing. Second, we must be able to concentrate on what we are doing. Third and fourth, the concentration is usually possible because the task undertaken has clear goals and provides immediate feedback.
key_quotes.relevance: The search phase must feel completable (finite, filterable results), focused (no distractions or irrelevant content), goal-directed (find housing matching my schedule and budget), and feedback-rich (each filter change immediately shows relevant results and pricing).

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Shomit wants to physically see the unit ('is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?' — line 29). This reveals that listing evaluation for a guest like Shomit is not purely digital — he needs sensory confirmation that the space is real and adequate. The book extract's discussion of the distinction between pleasure and enjoyment is directly relevant: Shomit is not looking for a luxurious experience (pleasure) but for a living arrangement that genuinely works for his life pattern (enjoyment through fit). His evaluation criteria are pragmatic: location, price, schedule compatibility. Csikszentmihalyi's insight about feedback is critical here — the listing page is where the guest must receive clear feedback on whether this property matches their needs. If the listing lacks key information (schedule availability, total monthly cost for their specific pattern, neighborhood context), the guest cannot complete their evaluation and will defer or abandon.

user_state.emotional_state: Analytically cautious. Shomit approaches evaluation like someone who has rented many apartments in NYC — he has a well-developed internal model of what constitutes good housing. He is measuring Split Lease listings against that model.
user_state.knowledge_level: Shomit understands the co-tenancy concept (explained on the call) but may not fully grasp how it affects his daily experience. He knows pricing is dynamic but has not yet seen actual listing pages or property details.
user_state.commitment_level: Evaluating with established criteria. He has a mental checklist (location, budget, schedule, space quality) but explicitly wants to compare multiple listings before acting on any single one.
user_state.data_available: From the call: property exists on Upper West Side at $66/night for 4 nights. Other properties available at various price points. Shomit has not yet seen photos, amenities, or detailed descriptions.

reasons: Shomit wants to physically visit the property, but the platform workflow may not easily accommodate in-person viewing before bidding. If there is no clear path to viewing, he may feel the process lacks the feedback he needs to commit.

His NYC rental experience creates high expectations for listing quality. If listings feel sparse, amateur, or lack the detail he would expect from a traditional rental listing, his trust in the platform drops.

The co-tenancy model means he is evaluating not just a space but a shared living arrangement. Uncertainty about the other person using the space ('Where does that other person go?' — line 18) adds an evaluation dimension that standard listings do not address.
dropout_risk.evidence: Shomit's question 'Where does that other person go?' (line 18) and his response 'I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.' (line 19) shows surface acceptance but underlying uncertainty. The repeated 'I guess' signals unresolved evaluation. Csikszentmihalyi: 'unless a person learns to set goals and to recognize and gauge feedback in such activities, she will not enjoy them.' (line 514-515). If the listing page does not provide clear feedback about the co-tenancy arrangement, guests cannot fully evaluate and will not enjoy (engage with) the process.

key_quotes.quote: is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?
key_quotes.relevance: Reveals the guest's need for direct sensory evaluation. Digital information alone is insufficient for commitment — the guest needs feedback that only physical presence or very rich media can provide.

key_quotes.quote: Where does that other person go? ... I mean, I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.
key_quotes.relevance: Triple hedging ('I guess... I guess... I guess') reveals unresolved evaluation of the co-tenancy model. The listing evaluation phase must address this uncertainty proactively.

key_quotes.quote: The reason it is possible to achieve such complete involvement in a flow experience is that goals are usually clear, and feedback immediate.
key_quotes.relevance: For listing evaluation to work, the guest must have clear goals (what am I evaluating?) and immediate feedback (does this property meet my criteria?). Ambiguity in either dimension breaks engagement.

key_quotes.quote: these blind women stressed more than anyone else the importance of receiving clear feedback as a condition for enjoying whatever they were doing. Unable to see what was going on around them, they needed to know even more than sighted people whether what they were trying to accomplish was actually coming to pass.
key_quotes.relevance: Guests evaluating listings remotely are in an analogous situation — they cannot see the actual space. They need richer, clearer feedback from the listing to compensate for the absence of direct sensory experience.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: The call reveals that proposal creation (bidding) is where Shomit's resistance is strongest. Despite the agent explaining three times that a bid is non-binding, Shomit refuses to place one: 'No, I want to see what the other options are' (line 52), 'I'll still hold off' (line 55). The book extract explains why: Csikszentmihalyi's paradox of control states that people enjoy 'not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations' (line 725-726). Shomit does not yet feel he has enough information to exercise control over his decision. Placing a bid — even a non-binding one — feels like surrendering control before he has mapped the decision landscape. The proposal creation phase demands that the guest feel sufficiently oriented and informed to act with confidence. If it feels premature, the guest will defer indefinitely, exactly as Shomit does.

user_state.emotional_state: Resistant but not hostile. Shomit appreciates the information ('this is good, right?' — line 23) but consistently deflects action. He wants to accumulate knowledge before exercising agency.
user_state.knowledge_level: Shomit understands that bids are non-binding and that he can enter multiple bids. But understanding the rule does not produce the feeling of control — he needs to have seen and compared options first.
user_state.commitment_level: Pre-commitment. He is gathering inputs for a future decision. The agent's encouragement to bid now is premature for his decision-making rhythm.
user_state.data_available: Shomit knows one property (Upper West Side, $66/night for 4 nights), knows the bid is non-binding, knows multiple bids are encouraged. He lacks: comparison of multiple listings, schedule confirmation, total cost clarity across different configurations.

reasons: This is the phase where the guest must take their first concrete platform action. Every prior interaction has been conversational (phone call). The transition from conversation to platform action is the highest-risk handoff in the guest journey.

Shomit's triple refusal to bid on the call suggests the bidding concept itself creates friction. Even 'non-binding' does not remove the sense that bidding is a commitment step. The word 'bid' carries connotations of obligation (auctions, contracts).

The two-to-three-week process timeline ('it usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process' — line 62) means Shomit must sustain engagement across multiple sessions. Each session re-entry is a new dropout opportunity.

There is no immediate feedback loop after placing a bid. The agent describes a process (bid -> matching -> Zoom meeting -> lease) with significant delays between steps. Csikszentmihalyi is clear that feedback must be immediate to sustain engagement.
dropout_risk.evidence: The agent says: 'So do not afraid to enter, see, or four or five bids, because at the end of the day you will sign the lease only as the one, which you like.' (line 54). Despite this reassurance, Shomit's immediate response is: 'I'll still hold off.' (line 55). Csikszentmihalyi: 'It is not possible to experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines. Only when a doubtful outcome is at stake, and one is able to influence that outcome, can a person really know whether she is in control.' (lines 727-730). Shomit is not yet willing to give up the safety of 'just looking' because he does not feel he can influence the outcome.

key_quotes.quote: You will receive a link to be able to see, not only is this property, but multiple properties. If you like as a bull parties, as well as this one, I would suggest entering the beat for this property... what happens is a bead is not Samsung, which obligates you to lease it. It's your expression of interest for certain properties.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent frames the bid as non-binding and encourages multiple bids. But the framing does not overcome Shomit's need for a sense of control through information gathering first.

key_quotes.quote: I'll still hold off. See the other ones. Right. I mean, it's good to know because, so let's say I get it right. I know I'm not committed to moving forward until I signed the lease.
key_quotes.relevance: Shomit anchors his sense of control to the lease signing — the final commitment point. Everything before that feels like premature commitment to him, even when framed as non-binding.

key_quotes.quote: what people enjoy is not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations. It is not possible to experience a feeling of control unless one is willing to give up the safety of protective routines. Only when a doubtful outcome is at stake, and one is able to influence that outcome, can a person really know whether she is in control.
key_quotes.relevance: For proposal creation to work, the guest must feel they have enough information to exercise control. Premature prompting to bid before the guest has surveyed options violates this principle.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: The call gives a preview of the negotiation phase through the agent's description of the matching and Zoom meeting process: 'we will create for you emitting. So you will meet on zoom that person, and you will talk to the tourist. So you will be able to say, I am comfortable or not comfortable with the other person who is going to use it to a party when you're not there.' (lines 57-58). This is a significant negotiation point that goes beyond price — the guest must evaluate a co-tenant. The book extract illuminates this phase powerfully through Signor Orsini's story about bargaining: 'I enjoy the clash of wits involved in bargaining, when two persons try to outdo each other with ruses and with eloquence' (lines 196-197). The negotiation phase has the potential to be either the most engaging (enjoyable) or most anxiety-producing part of the guest journey, depending on whether the guest feels like an active participant exercising skill or a passive party being evaluated.

user_state.emotional_state: Shomit has not yet reached this phase, but the call suggests he would approach it with the same cautious, information-gathering stance. His question about the other person ('Where does that other person go?' — line 18) indicates he is already thinking about co-tenant compatibility.
user_state.knowledge_level: Shomit knows a Zoom meeting with the co-tenant will occur but has no details about what to expect, what criteria to evaluate, or what his rights are if the meeting goes poorly.
user_state.commitment_level: Conditional. The agent made clear that even after the Zoom meeting, the guest is not committed until the lease is signed. This should reduce anxiety, but the emotional weight of meeting a stranger adds a new dimension of uncertainty.
user_state.data_available: Only the agent's verbal description of the matching process. No written materials, no profiles of potential co-tenants, no criteria for evaluation.

reasons: Meeting a stranger on Zoom to evaluate shared-living compatibility is a socially complex interaction that many people find uncomfortable. This is an unusual challenge with unclear 'skills' required — violating Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance principle.

There are no clear goals or evaluation criteria provided for this meeting. What should the guest be looking for? What constitutes a good match? Without explicit guidance, the guest must improvise, which produces anxiety rather than flow.

The negotiation phase introduces a dependency on another person (the co-tenant). The guest's progress now depends on someone else's availability and compatibility, which can feel like a loss of control.
dropout_risk.evidence: Csikszentmihalyi on socializing: 'of course, it does [require skills]; as so many shy people know, if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts, and avoid company whenever possible.' (lines 295-297). The Zoom co-tenant meeting is a high-stakes informal contact that could deter guests who are uncomfortable with such interactions.

key_quotes.quote: you will meet on zoom that person, and you will talk to the tourist. So you will be able to say, I am comfortable or not comfortable with the other person who is going to use it to a party when you're not there.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent frames the Zoom meeting as the guest's chance to exercise control (approve or reject the co-tenant). But the lack of structure around this interaction may undermine that sense of control.

key_quotes.quote: I enjoy the clash of wits involved in bargaining, when two persons try to outdo each other with ruses and with eloquence. She didn't even flinch. She didn't know any better. She didn't pay me the respect of assuming that I was going to try to take advantage of her. If I had sold those pieces to that woman at that ridiculous price, I would have felt cheated.
key_quotes.relevance: Signor Orsini's story shows that negotiation is enjoyable only when both parties are engaged and skilled. If the co-tenant Zoom call is a passive, scripted check rather than a genuine conversation, it loses its potential to create engagement and trust.

key_quotes.quote: Another universally enjoyable activity is being with other people. Socializing might at first sight appear to be an exception to the statement that one needs to use skills to enjoy an activity, for it does not seem that gossiping or joking around with another person requires particular abilities. But of course, it does; as so many shy people know, if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts, and avoid company whenever possible.
key_quotes.relevance: The co-tenant meeting is a social interaction that requires interpersonal skills. Guests who lack confidence in this area need structured support to make the interaction feel manageable rather than threatening.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: The call establishes lease signing as the definitive commitment point. Shomit explicitly anchors to this: 'I know I'm not committed to moving forward until I signed the lease' (line 55). The book extract's discussion of the autotelic experience is revealing here: Csikszentmihalyi distinguishes between activities done for extrinsic reasons (exotelic) and those done for intrinsic reward (autotelic). At the acceptance phase, the guest's motivation shifts from exotelic (solving a housing problem) to potentially autotelic (actually wanting to live in this specific place with this arrangement). The acceptance phase is where the guest either feels that the entire process has led to a genuinely good outcome — creating intrinsic satisfaction with the decision — or feels they are just settling for an adequate external solution. The former produces commitment and retention; the latter produces fragile compliance.

user_state.emotional_state: Not yet reached in this call. Based on Shomit's pattern, he would likely approach acceptance with relief (the decision is finalized) mixed with residual caution (is this really the right choice?).
user_state.knowledge_level: By this phase, the guest should know the property, the co-tenant, the price, the schedule, and the lease terms. But the call suggests significant knowledge gaps may persist about the day-to-day experience of shared living.
user_state.commitment_level: This is the phase where commitment becomes formal. The psychological weight of signing a lease is substantial for someone like Shomit who has extensive NYC rental experience and treats lease signing as a significant financial decision.
user_state.data_available: At this phase: property details, co-tenant meeting outcome, lease terms, total cost, schedule confirmed. What may be missing: practical details about key handoff, house rules, arrival procedures, cleaning expectations.

reasons: Last-moment hesitation is common in commitment phases. Shomit's pattern of deferral ('I'll still hold off') suggests he might request additional time or information even at this stage.
If the lease document introduces new terms, fees, or conditions not discussed in prior phases, trust is broken at the worst possible moment.
The two-to-three-week process duration means Shomit's circumstances or motivation may have changed by the time he reaches acceptance.
dropout_risk.evidence: Csikszentmihalyi: 'When experience is intrinsically rewarding life is justified in the present, instead of being held hostage to a hypothetical future gain.' (lines 1047-1048). If the acceptance phase feels like a bureaucratic obligation rather than the satisfying conclusion of a good decision process, it will not generate the intrinsic reward that strengthens commitment.

key_quotes.quote: I know I'm not committed to moving forward until I signed the lease.
key_quotes.relevance: Shomit treats lease signing as the singular commitment point. Everything before it is exploratory. The acceptance phase must honor this expectation and not introduce unexpected commitments.

key_quotes.quote: It's usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process and get Lisa [lease].
key_quotes.relevance: The extended timeline means the guest must sustain motivation across weeks. Each gap is a dropout risk. The acceptance phase needs to feel like a natural, satisfying conclusion rather than the end of a long bureaucratic ordeal.

key_quotes.quote: The key element of an optimal experience is that it is an end in itself. Even if initially undertaken for other reasons, the activity that consumes us becomes intrinsically rewarding. Surgeons speak of their work: 'It is so enjoyable that I would do it even if I didn't have to.'
key_quotes.relevance: The acceptance phase is where the guest journey either achieves autotelic quality (the guest feels genuinely good about the decision itself) or remains purely exotelic (the guest is just solving a housing problem). The former builds loyalty; the latter produces churn.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address the move-in phase — Shomit is far from moving in during this call. However, the call provides one important indirect signal: Shomit's request to physically see the unit ('is it possible to see the unit?' — line 29) suggests that the gap between digital listing and physical reality is a significant concern. The book extract's discussion of the merging of action and awareness is relevant: the move-in phase is where the guest's conceptual understanding of Split Lease merges with physical reality. Csikszentmihalyi describes how in flow, 'people become so involved in what they are doing that the activity becomes spontaneous, almost automatic' (lines 424-425). The move-in should be designed so that arrival and settling in feel smooth and natural rather than confusing or jarring. If the first physical experience contradicts the digital promise, the mismatch will be deeply disorienting.

user_state.emotional_state: Not yet reached. Anticipated state based on Shomit's profile: cautious optimism mixed with evaluative scrutiny. He will be comparing the physical space to his expectations from the listing and the call.
user_state.knowledge_level: By move-in, the guest should know the property, co-tenant, lease terms, and house rules. But practical knowledge (how to get in, where things are, what to do on arrival) is critical and may be lacking.
user_state.commitment_level: Fully committed (lease is signed). But commitment can erode rapidly if the move-in experience is poor.
user_state.data_available: All pre-lease information plus access to the House Manual. First-hand sensory data about the space begins at this phase.

reasons: First impressions of the physical space may not match listing expectations. For someone like Shomit with extensive NYC rental experience, even minor discrepancies will register as problems.
The shared-living reality becomes tangible: evidence of the co-tenant's presence, shared belongings, different living standards. This is where abstract understanding becomes concrete experience.
Practical friction (unclear check-in process, missing key, unclear house rules) can make the first experience frustrating rather than smooth.
dropout_risk.evidence: Csikszentmihalyi: 'the clearly structured demands of the activity impose order, and exclude the interference of disorder in consciousness.' (lines 620-621). Move-in must be clearly structured with explicit steps, or the guest's first physical experience will be disordered and anxiety-producing.

key_quotes.quote: is it possible to see the unit? Is that allowed?
key_quotes.relevance: The desire to see the unit before committing signals that Shomit values physical verification. If he did not get to see it beforehand, the move-in phase is the first moment of truth where digital promises meet physical reality.

key_quotes.quote: people become so involved in what they are doing that the activity becomes spontaneous, almost automatic; they stop being aware of themselves as separate from the actions they are performing.
key_quotes.relevance: The ideal move-in experience is one where the process is so well-designed that the guest flows naturally from arrival to settling in, without friction or confusion that forces them out of the experience.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: This lens does not directly address the active lease phase — the call is an initial inquiry and Shomit is months away from active tenancy. However, the book extract provides the deepest insights for this phase. Csikszentmihalyi's entire chapter is about how ongoing experience can be structured for enjoyment rather than mere pleasure. The active lease phase is where the guest's daily experience either becomes enjoyable (producing retention) or merely pleasant at best (producing eventual churn). The key insight: Split Lease must design the active lease experience to provide ongoing challenges matched to skills, clear goals, immediate feedback, and a sense of control — the elements of flow. If the active lease phase is purely administrative (pay rent, follow rules, clean up), it remains exotelic and fragile. If it includes elements that create genuine engagement — a sense of belonging, growing comfort with the arrangement, positive co-tenant interactions — it can become autotelic.

user_state.emotional_state: Not yet reached. Based on Shomit's profile: he would likely settle into a pragmatic routine, evaluating the arrangement against his benchmark of 'is this worth it compared to alternatives?'
user_state.knowledge_level: By active lease, the guest has full experiential knowledge of the arrangement. They know the space, the co-tenant dynamic, the platform's communication tools, and the rhythms of shared living.
user_state.commitment_level: Contractually committed but psychologically evaluating continuously. Each week is an implicit renewal of the decision to stay.
user_state.data_available: Full operational data: payment history, stay records, communication logs, cleaning photos, date change history, reviews.

reasons: The novelty of the arrangement wears off. Without ongoing positive experiences, the guest reverts to cost-benefit analysis and may find cheaper or more convenient alternatives.
Co-tenant friction or evidence of co-tenant negligence (unclean space, missing items, different living standards) can erode satisfaction rapidly.
If the platform becomes invisible during active lease (no engagement, no feedback, no check-ins), the guest feels unsupported and may not renew.

Csikszentmihalyi warns that 'pleasure helps to maintain order, but by itself cannot create new order in consciousness' (line 129). If the active lease provides only the pleasure of a comfortable space without the enjoyment of a growing, positive experience, it will not sustain long-term engagement.
dropout_risk.evidence: Csikszentmihalyi: 'Without enjoyment life can be endured, and it can even be pleasant. But it can be so only precariously, depending on luck and the cooperation of the external environment. To gain personal control over the quality of experience, however, one needs to learn how to build enjoyment into what happens day in, day out.' (lines 206-210). The active lease phase must build enjoyment (not just pleasure) into the ongoing experience to sustain it.

key_quotes.quote: the cost for you is significantly less everybody enjoys comfort of coming to the same home, the need to cause a star falls at times.
key_quotes.relevance: The agent frames active tenancy as 'comfort of coming to the same home.' This is the pleasure dimension. But Csikszentmihalyi shows that pleasure alone does not sustain engagement — the active lease phase must also provide enjoyment through growing mastery and satisfaction.

key_quotes.quote: Enjoyment is characterized by this forward movement: by a sense of novelty, of accomplishment. ... After an enjoyable event we know that we have changed, that our self has grown: in some respect, we have become more complex as a result of it.
key_quotes.relevance: The active lease phase should provide a sense of forward movement — the guest's living arrangement improving over time, their comfort growing, their relationship with the space deepening. This is what transforms a lease from a transaction into an experience.

key_quotes.quote: Pleasure is an important component of the quality of life, but by itself it does not bring happiness. Sleep, rest, food, and sex provide restorative homeostatic experiences that return consciousness to order after the needs of the body intrude and cause psychic entropy to occur. But they do not produce psychological growth.
key_quotes.relevance: A comfortable apartment provides pleasure. But the active lease phase must go beyond pleasure to create enjoyment — a sense that the living arrangement is actively contributing to the guest's quality of life and personal growth.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The guest demands a complete information landscape before taking any action — even non-binding actions. Each phase where the platform asks for commitment before the guest feels fully informed triggers resistance and deferral.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Shomit refuses to bid three times (lines 52, 55, 61) despite being told bids are non-binding. He wants to see all options first ('No, I want to see what the other options are' — line 52), understand his own timeline ('I'm not sure if when I would start' — line 52), and confirm he is not committed ('I know I'm not committed to moving forward until I signed the lease' — line 55). Csikszentmihalyi: 'what people enjoy is not the sense of being in control, but the sense of exercising control in difficult situations' (lines 725-726). Shomit cannot exercise control without first mapping the decision space.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Clear goals and immediate feedback are absent at critical transition points between phases, creating uncertainty gaps where the guest does not know what to do next or what to expect.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: The transition from call to platform is a gap: Shomit is told he will receive an email (line 32-33) but has no visibility into what happens next or when. The bidding system lacks immediate feedback: after placing a bid, the guest waits for a match with no clear timeline. The Zoom co-tenant meeting has no preparation materials or evaluation criteria. Csikszentmihalyi: 'the concentration is usually possible because the task undertaken has clear goals and provides immediate feedback' (lines 251-252). Each of these transition gaps violates this principle.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The co-tenancy model introduces a persistent layer of social uncertainty that the platform's current process addresses only verbally (on a phone call) rather than structurally (in the product).
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Shomit's question 'Where does that other person go?' (line 18) and his hedged acceptance ('I guess that's fine. I mean, it doesn't really matter to me. Well, I guess that's fine.' — line 19) show unresolved social uncertainty from discovery onward. The Zoom meeting addresses it at negotiation but only for a single moment. During active lease, co-tenant dynamics continue to be a source of potential friction. Csikszentmihalyi on socializing: 'if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts' (lines 295-296). The platform must structurally address co-tenant uncertainty at every relevant phase, not just once.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The guest's mental model of housing (formed by years of traditional NYC renting) creates friction with the Split Lease model at every phase. The platform must bridge from the familiar model to the new one rather than assuming the new model is self-explanatory.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Shomit says: 'I've had many leases I've rented in New York for a long time. I think go, like, what kind of place would I rent for myself? Right. Probably below 2,500 a month is what I would usually spend' (lines 67-68). He anchors his budget and expectations to traditional renting, then must mentally translate to Split Lease's per-night, partial-week pricing model. The agent must do this translation on the call (line 8: '$66 per night'). If the platform does not provide the same translation (monthly equivalent, comparison to alternatives), the guest must do cognitive work at every phase that the platform should do for them. Csikszentmihalyi: 'it would be a mistake to assume that only art and leisure can provide optimal experiences... one purpose of this book is to explore ways in which even routine details can be transformed into personally meaningful games' (lines 332-336). The platform can transform the pricing translation from a cognitive burden into a clear, immediate-feedback interaction.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The extended process timeline (two to three weeks) creates multiple re-engagement gaps where the guest must independently choose to return to the platform, with no automatic re-engagement mechanism described.
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: The agent says: 'it usually takes two or three weeks to finish the process and get Lisa [lease]' (line 62). Shomit responds: 'So like courtship' (line 61 — a telling metaphor: courtship requires sustained mutual interest with no guaranteed outcome). Each gap between sessions is a dropout point. Csikszentmihalyi: 'enjoyable activities that produce flow have a potentially negative aspect: while they are capable of improving the quality of existence by creating order in the mind, they can become addictive, at which point the self becomes captive' (lines 785-789). The opposite risk applies here: if the process does not maintain enough engagement between sessions, the guest's attention returns to the 'worries and frustrations of everyday life' (line 254) and the platform loses them.
